questions.question: The impudent child antagonized his teachers. What can replace impudent?
Freedom of speech is an inalienable right. What can replace inalienable?
questions.description: Inviolable and inalienable mean the same.

questions.question: The singer was offended by the inattentive audience. What can replace inattentive?
questions.description: Inattentive and distracted mean the same.

questions.question: The improvident heir quickly spent the family fortune.
questions.description: Improvident and spendthrift both means extravagant or wasteful.

questions.question: It was an inauspicious moment to start. What can replace inauspicious?
questions.description: Disastrous and inauspicious have similar meanings.

questions.question: She made some inane remarks about the weather. What can replace inane?
questions.description: Inane and ridiculous have similar meanings.

questions.question: The guest delivered an impromptu speech. What can replace impromptu?
questions.description: Improvised and impromptu both mean unprepared.

questions.question: There we came across many impoverished children. What can replace impoverished?
questions.description: Impoverished and destitute can both mean without means.

questions.question: The nuptial ceremony was very brief. What can replace nuptial?
The room was filled with noxious fumes. What can replace noxious?
Some animals are nocturnal feeders. What can replace nocturnal?
How can he be nonchalant in all this trouble? What can replace nonchalant?
The prisoner’s life was full of hardship and exertion. Here the word exertion can be replaced by …………………..
The comedian’s mockery of a senator making a speech was riotously funny. Here the word mockery can be replaced by …………………….
questions.description: Travesty means mockery or ludicrous imitation.

questions.question: In time of war, sedition is a crime punishable by death. The word sedition can be replaced by ………………….
Freezing rain made the road precarious. The word precarious can be replaced by ………………………
The sinner prayed that his misdeeds would be forgiven. Here the word misdeeds can be replaced by …………………..
Youthful beauty is temporary. The word temporary can be replaced by
questions.description: All of these words mean temporary.

questions.question: The heat and lack of sleep made everyone sluggish. Here the word sluggish can be replaced by …………………..
questions.description: Torpid means slow moving or inert.

questions.question: The principal delivered a tirade to the disobedient students. Here the word tirade can be replaced by ………………………..
questions.description: The words diatribe and tirade both mean a volley of words usually of censure.

questions.question: Even though she had plenty of money, the old woman was very frugal. Here the word frugal can be replaced by ......................................
He was so tight-lipped that no one knew whether he enjoyed the party or not. Here the word tight-lipped can be replaced by ……………………….
Stand up and fight for your rights instead of being submissive. Here the word submissive can be replaced by …………………………….
The mighty housing development dwarfed the rest of the neighborhood. Here the word mighty can be replaced by …………………………….
questions.description: Stupendous means vast, mighty or enormous.
